review: Very intuitive, I only use it to stream Sling TV and it works well.  EASY setup, amazon nailed that aspect of the player, I am not a computer whiz and it walked me right through the set up instructions.  Like how it "falls asleep" after 30 minutes to save energy and the only thing you need to do to "wake it up" is to push one of the buttons on the remote and it turns on my TV as well.  Only have used the voice recognition a couple of times and it worked perfectly.  I bought it with Sling TV and got it at half price which was nice.  Very nice toy to go with my TV, one has to be a fool to pay for cable.

review: Incredible little box, and the remote is fantastic! No more line of sight required, as it is Bluetooth. Still, a little extra buffering would be appreciated.

review: I previously was streaming Netflix and Amazon videos via a Sony Blu-Ray player that had internet connectivity.  That was OK, but it passed through a Sony server (from content provider to me), and I think that system was the weak link:  many times, my programming was unavailable when the Sony server went down, even though I clearly was still connected to the internet.  I wasn't using wireless, by the way.  I was connecting directly through Ethernet cable from a Time-Warner modem.  Video quality was just "OK," and the interface was comparatively clunky.Because the price was attractive and the reviews were generally good, I decided to switch to the Amazon Fire TV box.  Wow!  I'm really happy I did, and wish I'd done so long ago.  It has a great interface.  I perceive the picture quality to be improved over what I earlier experienced with the Sony system, probably because of superior speed.  The Fire TV is remarkably small, easily installed, but powerful.  [Note that I opted to purchase the Fire TV vs. the Fire Stick because I want to stream via Ethernet, rather than wireless network, although the Fire TV accommodates wireless connection, too.] The Amazon remote is wonderfully designed -- small, sleek, streamlined, with a minimum of buttons.  It offers many Apps I now use regularly (NetFlix*, HBO Go*, Mahogany, PBS Video, Smithsonian Channel, TED TV, History, YouTube, Sling, Showtime Anytime*, CBS News), plus dozens more you can load.  [Note:  (*) in my list means use of the particular App requires subscription fees].
